abstract.text: Make your apps accessible to everyone who uses iOS and tvOS apps.

media-3031607.alt: The four accessibility domain symbols for vision, hearing, physical and motor skills, and literacy and learning. From left-to-right, An eye icon, a speaker icon, an open hand icon, and an icon of upper and lowercase A characters.
media-3031607.title: Figure 1

abstract.text: A set of methods that provide accessibility information about views and controls in an app's user interface.
Provide a set of methods that view subclasses use to make subcomponents accessible as separate elements.
Learn how to make your iOS app more accessible to users who are blind or have low vision by adding VoiceOver support.
An informal protocol that provides a way to find out whether an assistive technology, such as VoiceOver, is focused on an accessible element.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
Methods to implement on an object that represents content that is intended to be read by users, such as a book or an article.
Methods to determine when to adjust images for different content size categories.
A set of methods that accessibility elements can use to support specific actions.
A custom action to be performed on an accessible object.
Make improvements to your app’s interaction model to support assistive technologies such as VoiceOver.
Encapsulates information about an item that should be accessible to users with disabilities, but that isn’t accessible by default.
A set of methods you can implement to provide accessibility information for a scroll view.
A set of methods you can implement to provide accessibility information for individual components of a picker view.
Methods that convey information about the contents of a table.
Methods that provide the location of a cell in a table.
Constants indicating the type of content stored in a data-based container.
A context-sensitive function that helps Voice Over users find the next instance of a related element.
A target element referenced by a custom rotor.
The search parameters that help determine the next matching custom rotor item result.
An accessibility descriptor for a specific geometric point of interest within a view, for use by assistive technologies.
Posts a notification to assistive applications.
Contains the names of notifications generated by the accessibility system.
Converts the specified rectangle from view coordinates to screen coordinates.
Converts the specified path object to screen coordinates and returns a new path object with the results.
Returns the element that is currently focused by the specified assistive technology.
Returns the current pairing status of MFi hearing aids.
Constants that specify how a hearing device is being used.
Warns users that application-specific gestures conflict with the system-defined Zoom accessibility gestures.
Transitions the app to or from Single App mode asynchronously.
Notifies the system that the app’s focus has changed to a new location.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled AssistiveTouch.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled VoiceOver.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled Switch Control.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled the Shake to Undo setting.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled the Closed Captions + SDH setting.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled the Bold Text setting.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled the Increase Contrast setting.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled the Grayscale option in the Color Filters setting.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled Guided Access.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled the Classic Invert setting.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled the Mono Audio setting.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled the Reduce Motion setting.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled the Reduce Transparency setting.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled the Speak Screen setting.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled the Speak Selection setting.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the user has enabled the On/Off Labels setting.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the user has turned on the Button Shapes accessibility setting.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the user has turned on Reduce Motion and the Prefer Cross-Fade Transitions accessibility setting.
Encapsulate your app's event-handling logic in gesture recognizers so that you can reuse that code throughout your app.
Bring drag and drop to your app by using interaction APIs with your views.
Support pointer interactions in your custom controls and views.
Handle double-tap user interactions on Apple Pencil.
Navigate the interface of your UIKit app using a remote or a game controller.
Simplify interactions with your app using menu systems, contextual menus, Home screen quick actions, and keyboard shortcuts.
Make your apps accessible to everyone who uses iOS and tvOS apps.

inlineContent.text: Accessibility features help a wide range of people interact with their devices. For many, accessibility is a necessity. For others, it’s a practicality. For example, closed captions can be necessary for someone who is deaf or hard of hearing, but also useful for someone watching a video in a noisy environment.

Whether you’re developing a new app, or updating an existing one, consider the needs of all the people who may use your app. People can personalize their devices by choosing which accessibility features give them the best user experience.

By designing your app with accessibility in mind, you make it possible for everyone to enjoy your app. For simplicity, there are four accessibility domains to keep in mind when thinking about your users:
Vision — A person may be blind or color blind, or have a vision challenge that makes focusing difficult.
Hearing — A person may be deaf, have partial hearing loss, or have difficulty hearing sounds within a certain range.
Physical and motor skills — A person with reduced mobility may have difficulty holding a device or tapping the interface.
Learning and literacy — A person may have difficulty remembering a sequence of steps, or they may find an overly complex user interface difficult to process and manage.

iOS provides a wealth of accessibility features—such as VoiceOver, Switch Control, and Assistive Touch—that your app can tap into simply by using standard UIKit controls. Resources are available to help you easily utilize these built-in tools.

Users can choose between automatic accessibility and the native accessibility of the app, based on user preference. By default, the native accessibility of the app is preferred. But if no accessibility is implemented in the app, automatic accessibility is applied.
